4. Call 911 to ensure public safety. The Maintenance Manager or his designated alternate will

5. Notify the appropriate agencies as required by law.
6. Within 48 hours, a complete investigation must be performed.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility recently completed a detailed ammonia refrigeration system mechanical integrity
inspection. These items have been prioritized and are being addressed by the maintenance
department. In addition, Dairy Farmers of America  St. Paul Beverage Solutions continually looks to improve the implementation procedures in place for managing the ammonia refrigeration system.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Dairy Farmers of America  St. Paul Beverage Solutions has an Emergency Action Plan in effect to provide the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, Ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Dairy Farmers of America  St. Paul Beverage Solutions is located at 2080 Rice Street in St Paul, Minnesota. The facility is approximately 0.27 miles South of MN-36 and 0.03 miles East of Rice Street. The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of light commercial, industrial, and residential areas.

The regulated material present at the facility and the focus of this study is anhydrous ammonia.
The facility uses ammonia as a refrigerant within a closed system. The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high-pressure liquid, low-pressure liquid, low-pressure vapor, high-pressure vapor, then back to high-pressure liquid) to provide refrigeration for cold storage and production.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION
STEPS

Dairy Farmers of America  St. Paul Beverage Solutions ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards.

The facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. The ammonia refrigeration system is equipped with various automatic process controls which ensure safe and efficient

operation of the compressors, condensers, evaporators, and other process equipment, and regulating valves. In addition, pressure relief valves automatically engage in the event the system experiences a very high-pressure situation. In case of an ammonia leak, ammonia detectors will provide an alert.

From an administrative standpoint, the facility has implemented a Process Safety Management
program for compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119 and a Risk Management Program for compliance
with 40 CFR Part 68.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:

"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its
threshold quantity in the process.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:

On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or

Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a))."

Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history verified during the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study on October 16, 2023, there has not been a release of ammonia that meets these criteria in the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The following summarizes the emergency response and notification procedures at the facility:

1. In the event of a spill, release, near miss, or threatened release involving ammonia, evacuate
the immediate area and report the situation to the area supervisor. If appropriate, hit the system
emergency stop button.
2. Area supervisor will contact the Maintenance Manager. If they are not available (e.g. off-site), then the highest ranking supervisor on-site is contacted at the front office. If needed, the Maintenance Manager is contacted using telephone calls.
3. When the evacuation alarm sounds, all employees should follow the evacuation procedures
and evacuate the plant to ensure their safety. Currently, the facility evacuate
